title: Venus Williams Breaks Age Record at Australian Open
summary: Venus Williams, aged 45, has been awarded the final women's wildcard for the Australian Open, setting a new record as the oldest female player to compete in the main draw of this Grand Slam event. This surpasses the previous record held by Kimiko Date, who was 44 when she played in 2015. Williams, a seven-time Grand Slam champion and former world number one, expressed gratitude for returning to Melbourne Park, where she has been a runner-up twice in 2003 and 2017. Her participation follows a recent return to the US Open in 2023, where she was the third-oldest woman in the Open era. Additionally, Williams has accepted a wildcard for the Hobart International warm-up event starting on January 12, alongside players like Emma Raducanu. Her last appearance at the Australian Open was in 2021, ending in a second-round loss to Sara Errani. This wildcard highlights her enduring career and the tournament's recognition of her legacy in tennis.

background_read: The Australian Open is one of the four Grand Slam tennis tournaments, held annually in Melbourne, Australia. Wildcards are entries given to players who do not qualify through rankings, often to promote the sport or honor legendary players. Venus Williams is an American tennis icon, known for her powerful play and longevity in the sport, with seven Grand Slam singles titles. Her career spans decades, and she has faced challenges like injuries and age, but continues to compete. The Open era began in 1968, allowing professional players to participate in major tournaments, changing the landscape of tennis.
